natural problem:
Solve
\[\frac{(x + 7)(x - 2)}{x - 1} < 0.\]Enter your answer using interval notation.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "((x + 7)*(x - 2)) / (x - 1) < 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (x < -7 \<or> (x > 1 \<and> x < 2))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Solve
\[\frac{(x + 7)(x - 2)}{x - 1} < 0.\]Enter your answer using interval notation. The final Answer is (-\infty,-7) \cup (1,2)
 ### Proof
 We can build a sign chart: \[ \begin{array}{c|cccc} & x < -7 & -7 < x < 1 & 1 < x < 2 & 2 < x \\ \hline x + 7 & - & + & + & + \\ x - 1 & - & - & + & + \\ x - 2 & - & - & - & + \\ \frac{(x + 7)(x - 2)}{x - 1} & - & + & - & +
 \end{array} \]Thus, the solution is $x \in \boxed{(-\infty,-7) \cup (1,2)}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "((x + 7)*(x - 2)) / (x - 1) < 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (x < -7 \<or> (x > 1 \<and> x < 2))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For what values of $x$ is the expression $\frac{(x + 7)(x - 2)}{x - 1}$ less than zero? The final answer is $x < -7$ or $1 < x < 2$.

a_1.informal problem: Find the range of the real number x such that the inequality $\frac{(x + 7) * (x - 2)}{(x - 1)} < 0$ holds. The solution is that x is less than -7 or x is in the interval (1,2).
